_**Planet of the Apes**_ is an American [science
fiction](/wiki/Science_fiction "Science fiction") [media
franchise](/wiki/Media_franchise "Media franchise") consisting of films,
books, television series, comics, and other media about a world in which
humans and intelligent apes clash for control. The series began with French
author [Pierre Boulle](/wiki/Pierre_Boulle "Pierre Boulle")'s 1963 novel _[La
Planète des Singes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(novel\) "Planet of the Apes
\(novel\)")_ , translated into English as _Planet of the Apes_ or _Monkey
Planet_. The 1968 film adaptation, _[Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(1968_film\) "Planet of the Apes \(1968
film\)")_ , was a critical and commercial hit, initiating a series of sequels,
tie-ins, and derivative works. [Arthur P. Jacobs](/wiki/Arthur_P._Jacobs
"Arthur P. Jacobs") produced the series under APJAC Productions until his
death in 1973; since then [20th Century Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th
Century Fox") has owned the franchise.

Four sequels followed the original film between 1970 and 1973: _[Beneath the
Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Beneath_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Beneath the Planet
of the Apes")_ , _[Escape from the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Escape_from_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Escape from the Planet of the
Apes")_ , _[Conquest of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Conquest_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Conquest of the Planet of the
Apes")_ , and _[Battle for the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Battle_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Battle for the Planet of the
Apes")_. They did not approach the critical acclaim of the original, but were
commercially successful. The series also spawned two television series in 1974
and 1975. Plans for a film remake stalled in "[development
hell](/wiki/Development_hell "Development hell")" for over ten years before
[Tim Burton](/wiki/Tim_Burton "Tim Burton")'s _[Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(2001_film\) "Planet of the Apes \(2001
film\)")_ was released in 2001. A new [reboot](/wiki/Reboot_\(fiction\)
"Reboot \(fiction\)") film series commenced in 2011 with _[Rise of the Planet
of the Apes](/wiki/Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Rise of the Planet of the
Apes")_ , which was followed by _[Dawn of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes")_
in 2014 and _[War for the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "War for the Planet of the Apes")_
in 2017. The films have grossed a total of over $2 billion worldwide, against
a combined budget of $567.5 million. Other media and merchandising tie-ins
include books, comics, video games, and toys.

_Planet of the Apes_ has received particular attention for its treatment of
[race](/wiki/Race_\(human_categorization\) "Race \(human categorization\)"),
which critics consider its primary theme. Critics have also written on its
[Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") and [animal rights](/wiki/Animal_rights
"Animal rights") themes. The series has had a wide influence on subsequent
films, media, and art, as well as popular culture and political discourse.

## _La Planète des
Singes_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: La Planète des Singes")]

Main article: [Planet of the Apes (novel)](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(novel\)
"Planet of the Apes \(novel\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Planet_of_the_Apes_book_cover.jpg/200px-
Planet_of_the_Apes_book_cover.jpg)](/wiki/File:Planet_of_the_Apes_book_cover.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Planet_of_the_Apes_book_cover.jpg "Enlarge")

First American edition of Boulle's novel, titled _Planet of the Apes_

The series began with French author [Pierre Boulle](/wiki/Pierre_Boulle
"Pierre Boulle")'s 1963 novel _[La Planète des
Singes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(novel\) "Planet of the Apes \(novel\)")_.
Boulle wrote the novel in six months after the "humanlike expressions" of
gorillas at the zoo inspired him to contemplate the relationship between man
and ape. _La Planète des Singes_ was heavily influenced by 18th- and 19th-
century fantastical [travel narratives](/wiki/Travel_narrative "Travel
narrative"), especially [Jonathan Swift](/wiki/Jonathan_Swift "Jonathan
Swift")'s satirical _[Gulliver's Travels](/wiki/Gulliver%27s_Travels
"Gulliver's Travels")_. It is one of several of Boulle's works to use science
fiction tropes and plot devices to comment on the failings of human nature and
mankind's overreliance on technology. However, Boulle rejected the science
fiction label for his work, instead terming it "social fantasy".[1]

The novel is a social satire following French journalist Ulysse Mérou, who
participates in a voyage to a distant planet where speechless, animalistic
humans are hunted and enslaved by an advanced society of apes. Eventually
Mérou discovers that humans once dominated the planet until their complacency
allowed the more industrious apes to overthrow them. The novel's central
message is that human intelligence is not a fixed quality and could atrophy if
taken for granted.[1][2] Boulle considered the novel one of his minor works,
though it proved to be a hit. [Xan Fielding](/wiki/Xan_Fielding "Xan
Fielding") translated it into English; it was published in the United Kingdom
as _Monkey Planet_ and in the United States as _Planet of the Apes_.[3]

## Original film
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Original film series")]

Boulle's literary agent Allain Bernheim brought the novel to the attention of
American film producer [Arthur P. Jacobs](/wiki/Arthur_P._Jacobs "Arthur P.
Jacobs"), who had come to Paris looking for new properties to adapt with his
new company, APJAC Productions. To explain his interests, Jacobs had mentioned
to agents, "I wish _[King Kong](/wiki/King_Kong_\(1933_film\) "King Kong
\(1933 film\)")_ hadn't been made so I could make it." Bernheim initially
approached Jacobs about a [Françoise Sagan](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7oise_Sagan
"Françoise Sagan") novel, which Jacobs turned down. Remembering Jacobs'
earlier comment about _King Kong_ , Bernheim mentioned _La Planète des Singes_
, not expecting Jacobs would be interested. However, the story intrigued
Jacobs, who bought the film rights immediately.[4]

### _Planet of the Apes_
(1968)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Planet of the Apes \(1968\)")]

Main article: [Planet of the Apes (1968
film)](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(1968_film\) "Planet of the Apes \(1968
film\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Charlton_Heston_Civil_Rights_March_1963.jpg/150px-
Charlton_Heston_Civil_Rights_March_1963.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charlton_Heston_Civil_Rights_March_1963.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charlton_Heston_Civil_Rights_March_1963.jpg "Enlarge")

[Charlton Heston](/wiki/Charlton_Heston "Charlton Heston"), star of _Planet of
the Apes_

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Franklin_J._Schaffner.jpg/150px-
Franklin_J._Schaffner.jpg)](/wiki/File:Franklin_J._Schaffner.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Franklin_J._Schaffner.jpg "Enlarge")

[Franklin J. Schaffner](/wiki/Franklin_J._Schaffner "Franklin J. Schaffner"),
director of _Planet of the Apes_

After optioning the novel's film rights, Arthur P. Jacobs spent over three
years trying to convince filmmakers to take on the project. He hired a
succession of artists to create test sketches, and hired veteran television
writer [Rod Serling](/wiki/Rod_Serling "Rod Serling"), creator of _[The
Twilight Zone](/wiki/The_Twilight_Zone "The Twilight Zone")_ , to pen the
script.[5][6] Serling's script changed elements of Boulle's novel, introducing
[Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") themes; notably he wrote a new twist
ending that revealed the planet to be a future Earth where humans had
destroyed themselves through [nuclear warfare](/wiki/Nuclear_warfare "Nuclear
warfare").[7] As production costs were estimated at over $10 million, no
studio in either Hollywood or Europe would assume the risk. Jacobs and
associate producer [Mort Abrahams](/wiki/Mort_Abrahams "Mort Abrahams")
persevered, and eventually persuaded [Charlton Heston](/wiki/Charlton_Heston
"Charlton Heston") to star; Heston in turn recommended director [Franklin J.
Schaffner](/wiki/Franklin_J._Schaffner "Franklin J. Schaffner"). The team
recorded a brief [screen test](/wiki/Screen_test "Screen test") featuring
Heston, which ultimately convinced [20th Century Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox
"20th Century Fox") the film could succeed.[5]

Fox insisted on changes to reduce the budget to a more manageable $5.8
million.[8] The producers hired veteran writer [Michael
Wilson](/wiki/Michael_Wilson_\(writer\) "Michael Wilson \(writer\)"), who had
previously [adapted](/wiki/The_Bridge_on_the_River_Kwai "The Bridge on the
River Kwai") Boulle's novel _[The Bridge over the River
Kwai](/wiki/The_Bridge_over_the_River_Kwai "The Bridge over the River Kwai")_
, to rewrite Serling's script.[9][10] To save on special effects costs,
Wilson's script described an ape society more primitive than that which
appeared in the novel.[10][11] The new script changed much of the plot and
dialogue, but retained the Cold War themes and Serling's ending.[11][12] [John
Chambers](/wiki/John_Chambers_\(make-up_artist\) "John Chambers \(make-up
artist\)") created the innovative makeup effects.[13]

Heston played 20th-century American astronaut [George
Taylor](/wiki/George_Taylor_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "George Taylor \(Planet of
the Apes\)"), who travels to a strange planet where intelligent apes dominate
mute, primitive humans. [Kim Hunter](/wiki/Kim_Hunter "Kim Hunter") and [Roddy
McDowall](/wiki/Roddy_McDowall "Roddy McDowall") played the sympathetic
chimpanzees [Zira](/wiki/Zira_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Zira \(Planet of the
Apes\)") and [Cornelius](/wiki/Cornelius_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Cornelius
\(Planet of the Apes\)"), and [Linda
Harrison](/wiki/Linda_Harrison_\(actress\) "Linda Harrison \(actress\)")
portrayed Taylor's love interest [Nova](/wiki/Nova_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\)
"Nova \(Planet of the Apes\)"). [Maurice Evans](/wiki/Maurice_Evans_\(actor\)
"Maurice Evans \(actor\)") played the villain, orangutan science minister [Dr.
Zaius](/wiki/Dr._Zaius "Dr. Zaius").[14] The finale, in which Taylor comes
upon a ruined [Statue of Liberty](/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty "Statue of Liberty")
and realizes he has been on Earth all along, became the series' defining scene
and one of the most iconic images in 1960s film.[15] The film was released on
February 8, 1968, and was a smash success with both critics and audiences,
breaking contemporary box office records and earning rave reviews.[16] John
Chambers received an honorary Oscar at the [41st Academy
Awards](/wiki/41st_Academy_Awards "41st Academy Awards") for his make-up
effects, the first ever given to a make-up artist.[13] [Jerry
Goldsmith](/wiki/Jerry_Goldsmith "Jerry Goldsmith")'s score and [Morton
Haack](/wiki/Morton_Haack "Morton Haack")'s costume design also earned Oscar
nominations.[17] Fox approached Jacobs and Abrahams about filming a sequel.
Though they had not made the film with sequels in mind, its success led them
to consider the prospect.[16]

### _Beneath the Planet of the Apes_
(1970)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Beneath the Planet of the Apes \(1970\)")]

Main article: [Beneath the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Beneath_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Beneath the Planet of the Apes")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Kim_Hunter_%28A_Streetcar_Named_Desire%2C_1951%29.jpg/150px-
Kim_Hunter_%28A_Streetcar_Named_Desire%2C_1951%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kim_Hunter_\(A_Streetcar_Named_Desire,_1951\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kim_Hunter_\(A_Streetcar_Named_Desire,_1951\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Kim Hunter](/wiki/Kim_Hunter "Kim Hunter") played
[Zira](/wiki/Zira_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Zira \(Planet of the Apes\)") in the
first three films

Planning for the sequel, eventually titled _[Beneath the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Beneath_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Beneath the Planet of the Apes")_
, began two months after the original film's release. Jacobs and Abrahams
initially considered several treatments by Rod Serling and Pierre Boulle, but
ultimately turned them down.[18] In fall 1968 the producers hired [Paul
Dehn](/wiki/Paul_Dehn "Paul Dehn") to write the script; he would become the
primary writer for the franchise.[19][20] Charlton Heston was uninterested in
a sequel, but agreed to shoot a few scenes if his character were killed off
and his salary donated to charity.[21] In one of many major rewrites, Dehn
altered the script to center on a new character,
[Brent](/wiki/Brent_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Brent \(Planet of the Apes\)"),
played by [James Franciscus](/wiki/James_Franciscus "James Franciscus").[22]
With director Franklin J. Shaffner unavailable, owing to his work on
_[Patton](/wiki/Patton_\(film\) "Patton \(film\)")_ , the producers hired [Ted
Post](/wiki/Ted_Post "Ted Post") on January 8, 1969.[23] Post struggled with
the material, especially after the studio cut the budget to $3.4 million.[24]

The story follows Franciscus' character Brent, an astronaut who inadvertently
follows Taylor into the future while searching for him. After encountering the
apes from the first film, Brent finds Taylor imprisoned by a colony of
subterranean human mutants who worship an ancient [nuclear
bomb](/wiki/Nuclear_bomb "Nuclear bomb"). Kim Hunter, Maurice Evans, and Linda
Harrison returned as Zira, Zaius, and Nova.[25] [David
Watson](/wiki/David_Watson_\(actor\) "David Watson \(actor\)") replaced Roddy
McDowall as Cornelius, as McDowall was unavailable due to a scheduling
conflict.[26] [James Gregory](/wiki/James_Gregory_\(actor\) "James Gregory
\(actor\)") played gorilla [General Ursus](/wiki/General_Ursus "General
Ursus") and [Paul Richards](/wiki/Paul_Richards_\(actor\) "Paul Richards
\(actor\)") played mutant leader
[Méndez](/wiki/M%C3%A9ndez_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Méndez \(Planet of the
Apes\)"). The film opened on May 26, 1970.[25] Unlike the first film,
_Beneath_ was poorly reviewed; critics typically regard it as the worst of the
_Apes_ sequels other than the fifth film, _[Battle for the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Battle_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Battle for the Planet of the
Apes")_.[27] However, it was a major box office hit, nearing the original's
numbers. Despite a conclusion depicting the planet's nuclear destruction, Fox
requested another sequel, creating a series.[28][29]

### _Escape from the Planet of the Apes_
(1971)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Escape from the Planet of the Apes \(1971\)")]

Main article: [Escape from the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Escape_from_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Escape from the Planet of the
Apes")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/RoddyMcDowall.jpg/150px-
RoddyMcDowall.jpg)](/wiki/File:RoddyMcDowall.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RoddyMcDowall.jpg "Enlarge")

[Roddy McDowall](/wiki/Roddy_McDowall "Roddy McDowall") returned as
[Cornelius](/wiki/Cornelius_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Cornelius \(Planet of the
Apes\)") in _Escape from the Planet of the Apes_. He would go on to star in
two additional _Apes_ films and the live-action television series

Following the financial success of _Beneath_ , Arthur P. Jacobs recruited Paul
Dehn to write a new script with a brief telegram: "Apes exist, Sequel
required." Dehn immediately started work on what became _[Escape from the
Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Escape_from_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Escape from the
Planet of the Apes")_. The producers hired a new director, [Don
Taylor](/wiki/Don_Taylor_\(American_actor_and_director\) "Don Taylor
\(American actor and director\)").[29] Fox gave the production a greatly
diminished budget ($2.5 million), which required a tight production
schedule.[30]

To work around the budget, as well as _Beneath_ 's seemingly definitive
ending, the film took the series in a new direction by transporting Zira (Kim
Hunter) and Cornelius (Roddy McDowall, returning to the role after being
absent from _Beneath_) back in time to the contemporary United States,
reducing the need for expensive sets and ape make-up effects.[24] In the film,
Zira and Cornelius are initially accepted by American society, but fears that
their child will bring about the domination of the human race by evolved apes
leads to conflict. Jacob's wife [Natalie Trundy](/wiki/Natalie_Trundy "Natalie
Trundy"), who appeared as a mutant in _Beneath_ and later played the ape
[Lisa](/wiki/Lisa_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Lisa \(Planet of the Apes\)") in the
next two sequels, was cast as Dr. Stephanie Branton.[31] [Bradford
Dillman](/wiki/Bradford_Dillman "Bradford Dillman") played Dr. Lewis Dixon,
[Ricardo Montalbán](/wiki/Ricardo_Montalb%C3%A1n "Ricardo Montalbán") played
[Armando](/wiki/Armando_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Armando \(Planet of the
Apes\)"), and [Eric Braeden](/wiki/Eric_Braeden "Eric Braeden") portrayed the
villain, the President's Science Advisor [Otto Hasslein](/wiki/Otto_Hasslein
"Otto Hasslein").[32]

Compared to its predecessors, _Escape_ dwelt more heavily on themes of racial
conflict, which became a primary focus through the rest of the series.[33] The
film opened on May 21, 1971, less than a year after _Beneath_. It was well
received by critics.[34] From this point critics began seeing the films less
as independent units and more as installments in a greater work; Frederick S.
Clarke wrote that the burgeoning series had "the promise of being the first
epic of filmed science fiction."[35] It also performed well at the box office,
though not as strongly as its predecessors. Fox ordered a third sequel.[36]

### _Conquest of the Planet of the Apes_
(1972)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Conquest of the Planet of the Apes \(1972\)")]

Main article: [Conquest of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Conquest_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Conquest of the Planet of the
Apes")

Based on the strong positive response to _Escape_ , Fox ordered _[Conquest of
the Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Conquest_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Conquest of
the Planet of the Apes")_ , though it provided a comparatively low budget of
$1.7 million.[36] Paul Dehn returned as the scriptwriter, and producer Jacobs
hired [J. Lee Thompson](/wiki/J._Lee_Thompson "J. Lee Thompson") to direct.
Thompson had worked with Jacobs on two earlier films as well as during the
initial stages of _Planet_ , but scheduling conflicts had made him unavailable
during its long development process.[37] For _Conquest_ , Thompson and Dehn
focused heavily on the racial conflict theme, an ancillary concern in the
early films that became a major theme in _Escape_.[38] In particular, Dehn
associated the apes with African-Americans and modeled the plot after the 1966
[Watts Riots](/wiki/Watts_Riots "Watts Riots") and other episodes from the
[Civil Rights Movement](/wiki/Civil_Rights_Movement "Civil Rights
Movement").[37] Roddy McDowall signed on to play
[Caesar](/wiki/Caesar_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Caesar \(Planet of the Apes\)"),
the son of his previous character Cornelius.[39] Ricardo Montalban returned as
Armando, while [Don Murray](/wiki/Don_Murray_\(actor\) "Don Murray \(actor\)")
played [Governor Breck](/wiki/Governor_Breck "Governor Breck"), [Severn
Darden](/wiki/Severn_Darden "Severn Darden") played
[Kolp](/wiki/Kolp_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Kolp \(Planet of the Apes\)"), and
[Hari Rhodes](/wiki/Hari_Rhodes "Hari Rhodes") played
[MacDonald](/wiki/MacDonald_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "MacDonald \(Planet of the
Apes\)").[40]

Following _Escape_ , _Conquest_ is set in a near future where humans have
turned apes into slaves; Caesar rises from bondage to lead an ape rebellion.
The film opened June 30, 1972.[40] Reviews were mixed. However, the ending
left the series open to another sequel, and _Conquest_ was successful enough
at the box office that Fox greenlit another film.[41]

### _Battle for the Planet of the Apes_
(1973)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Battle for the Planet of the Apes \(1973\)")]

Main article: [Battle for the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Battle_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Battle for the Planet of the
Apes")

Fox approved _[Battle for the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Battle_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Battle for the Planet of the
Apes")_ with a $1.2 million budget, the lowest of the series.[42] The
filmmakers went into the project knowing it would be the last of the
series.[43] J. Lee Thompson returned as director. Series writer Paul Dehn
submitted a treatment, but illness forced him to leave the film before
completing the script. The producers subsequently hired [John William
Corrington](/wiki/John_William_Corrington "John William Corrington") and
[Joyce Hooper Corrington](/wiki/Joyce_Hooper_Corrington "Joyce Hooper
Corrington") to write the screenplay.[44][45] _Battle_ continued _Conquest_ 's
focus on racial conflict and domination. However, likely based in part on the
studio's wishes, the Corringtons discarded Dehn's pessimistic treatment in
favor of a story with a more hopeful, though ambiguous, resolution.[46]

_Battle_ follows Caesar as he leads the apes and their human subjects after a
devastating war that destroyed much of the planet. He contends with both an
attack by radiation-scarred human mutants and a coup attempt as he attempts to
build a better society for both apes and humans. McDowall returned as Caesar,
and Severn Darden returned as Kolp. [Paul
Williams](/wiki/Paul_Williams_\(songwriter\) "Paul Williams \(songwriter\)")
played the orangutan [Virgil](/wiki/Virgil_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Virgil
\(Planet of the Apes\)"), [Austin Stoker](/wiki/Austin_Stoker "Austin Stoker")
played [MacDonald](/wiki/MacDonald_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "MacDonald \(Planet
of the Apes\)") (the brother of Hari Rhodes' character), and [Claude
Akins](/wiki/Claude_Akins "Claude Akins") played the evil gorilla general
[Aldo](/wiki/Aldo_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Aldo \(Planet of the Apes\)"). [John
Huston](/wiki/John_Huston "John Huston") played the orangutan
[Lawgiver](/wiki/Lawgiver_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Lawgiver \(Planet of the
Apes\)") in a [frame narrative](/wiki/Frame_narrative "Frame narrative").[47]
The film opened May 2, 1973. It made a profit over production costs, but
received poor reviews from critics, who regard it as the weakest of the five
films.[48]

Critics have offered various interpretations of the film's message and its
significance for the series. Particular attention has been paid to the
ambiguous imagery in the ending: set 700 years after the main events, the last
scene depicts a statue of Caesar shedding a single tear as the Lawgiver
recounts Caesar's story to an integrated audience of ape and human children.
By one interpretation, the statue cries tears of joy because the species have
broken the cycle of oppression, giving the series an optimistic finale. By
another, the statue weeps because racial strife still exists, implying the
dystopian future of _Planet_ and _Beneath_ is unavoidable.[49]

## Television
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Television series")]

### _Planet of the Apes_ TV
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Planet of the Apes TV series")]

Main article: [Planet of the Apes (TV
series)](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(TV_series\) "Planet of the Apes \(TV
series\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Planet_of_the_Apes_cast_1974.JPG/200px-
Planet_of_the_Apes_cast_1974.JPG)](/wiki/File:Planet_of_the_Apes_cast_1974.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Planet_of_the_Apes_cast_1974.JPG "Enlarge")

The cast of the _Planet of the Apes_ television series: [James
Naughton](/wiki/James_Naughton "James Naughton") as Burke, [Ron
Harper](/wiki/Ron_Harper_\(actor\) "Ron Harper \(actor\)") as Virdon, and
Roddy McDowall as Galen

In addition to their box office grosses, the films earned very high ratings
when broadcast on television after their theatrical run. To capitalize on this
success, Arthur P. Jacobs conceived of an hour-long live action television
series to follow the films. He originally thought of the idea in 1971 during
the production of _Conquest_ , which he then anticipated would be the final
film. However, he shelved the project once Fox ordered a fifth film. Jacobs
died on June 27, 1973, bringing an end to the APJAC Productions era of the
_Planet of the Apes_ franchise. Former Fox executive [Stan
Hough](/wiki/Stan_Hough "Stan Hough") took over as producer for the television
project, titled _[Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(TV_series\)
"Planet of the Apes \(TV series\)")_. [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS") picked up the
series for its 1974 fall lineup.[50]

[Ron Harper](/wiki/Ron_Harper_\(actor\) "Ron Harper \(actor\)") and [James
Naughton](/wiki/James_Naughton "James Naughton") played Alan Virdon and Peter
Burke, two 20th-century American astronauts who pass through a time warp to a
future where apes subjugate humans (unlike the original film, the humans can
speak). Roddy McDowall returned to the franchise as Galen, a chimpanzee who
joins the astronauts. [Booth Coleman](/wiki/Booth_Coleman "Booth Coleman")
played orangutan Councillor [Zaius](/wiki/Zaius "Zaius") and [Mark
Lenard](/wiki/Mark_Lenard "Mark Lenard") played gorilla General Urko. The
episodes portray Virdon, Burke, and Galen as they look for answers, aid
downtrodden humans and apes, and avoid the authorities.[51] The show premiered
on September 13, 1974, filling CBS' 8–9 p.m. time slot on Fridays. It earned
low ratings during its run, a fact the production team attributed to
repetitive storytelling and too little screen time for the apes who made the
series famous. Given the considerable production costs, CBS cancelled the show
after 14 episodes, the last airing on December 20, 1974.[52][53][54]

In 1981, Fox reedited ten of the episodes into five [television
films](/wiki/Television_film "Television film"). Each film combined two
episodes and (in some markets) added new introductory and concluding segments
starring Roddy McDowall as an aged Galen. The films were given what scholar
Eric Greene called "the most outlandish titles of the _Apes_ corpus": _Back to
the Planet of the Apes_ ; _Forgotten City of the Planet of the Apes_ ;
_Treachery and Greed on the Planet of the Apes_ ; _Life, Liberty and Pursuit
on the Planet of the Apes_ ; and _Farewell to the Planet of the Apes_.[55]

Greene finds the show's timeline significant: set in 3085, it occurs about 900
years before Taylor's crash in the original film, and 400 years after the
Lawgiver's sermon in _Battle_. By depicting a future where apes dominate
humans, it implies the Lawgiver's message of equality between man and ape has
failed, giving weight to the more pessimistic interpretation of _Battle_ 's
ending.[56] Greene writes that the show emphasized the theme of racial
conflict less than the films had, though the episodes "The Trap" and "The
Liberator" made it the central focus.[57] However, the show is actually set in
the original timeline, before Caesar came to exist.

### Animated
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Animated series")]

#### _Return to the Planet of the
Apes_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Return to the Planet of the Apes")]

Main article: [Return to the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Return_to_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Return to the Planet of the
Apes")

In 1975, after the failure of the live-action series, [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC")
decided to adapt _Planet of the Apes_ for an animated series. The network
contracted [DePatie-Freleng Enterprises](/wiki/DePatie-Freleng_Enterprises
"DePatie-Freleng Enterprises") to produce a half-hour [Saturday morning
cartoon](/wiki/Saturday_morning_cartoon "Saturday morning cartoon") titled
_[Return to the Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Return_to_the_Planet_of_the_Apes
"Return to the Planet of the Apes")_. [Doug Wildey](/wiki/Doug_Wildey "Doug
Wildey"), co-creator of _[Jonny Quest](/wiki/Jonny_Quest "Jonny Quest")_ ,
took on most creative control as associate producer, storyboard director, and
supervising director.[58] Wildey had only watched the original film and
_Beneath_ , and thus based his interpretation on them. As such, the show
relied less on the themes and plot developments from _Escape_ , _Conquest_ ,
and _Battle_ and instead returned to the [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War
"Vietnam War") and Cold War themes prominent in the first two films.[59]

The plot concerns three American astronauts, Bill Hudson (Tom Williams), Jeff
Allen ([Austin Stoker](/wiki/Austin_Stoker "Austin Stoker"), who played
MacDonald in _Battle_), and Judy Franklin ([Claudette
Nevins](/wiki/Claudette_Nevins "Claudette Nevins")), who inadvertently journey
to Earth's far future. They find the world populated by three groups: mute
humans who inhabit desert caves, subterranean human "Underdwellers" fashioned
after the mutants of _Beneath_ , and civilized apes who subjugate the humans.
Through the show, the astronauts become increasingly involved in the planet's
affairs and in defending the humans against an ape invasion. The cast featured
characters based on those from the previous films and TV series, including
Nova (Claudette Nevis), General Urko (Henry Cordin), Zira (Philippa Harris),
Cornelius (Edwin Mills), and Dr. Zaius (Richard Blackburn).[60] NBC broadcast
thirteen episodes between September 6 and November 21, 1975.[61] The show did
not achieve particularly strong ratings. The network considered producing a
second three-episode season to complete the story, but this never
materialized.[62]

## Remake
film[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Remake film")]

### Planned relaunch and "development
hell"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Planned relaunch and "development hell"")]

Fox initiated plans to relaunch the _Planet of the Apes_ series in the 1980s,
but the project fell into "[development hell](/wiki/Development_hell
"Development hell")" for over ten years, experiencing one of the most
protracted development periods in film history. It began in 1988, when Fox
announced [Adam Rifkin](/wiki/Adam_Rifkin "Adam Rifkin"), then a 21-year-old
[independent film](/wiki/Independent_film "Independent film") director, would
develop a new _Apes_ film. At a Fox executive's invitation, Rifkin pitched a
concept for _Return to the Planet of the Apes_ , an alternative sequel to
_Planet_ that ignored the other four films. In Rifkin's initial concept,
Taylor's descendant Duke launches a [Spartacus](/wiki/Spartacus
"Spartacus")-like uprising against Roman-inspired ape oppressors led by
General Izan. The project nearly entered [pre-production](/wiki/Pre-production
"Pre-production"), but days before, Fox brought in new studio executives who
sent the project back to development.[63] They commissioned Rifkin to rewrite
the script through several drafts, but found them unsatisfactory and
ultimately scrapped the project.[64]

After several years in limbo, Fox returned to the _Apes_ concept, this time
with [Oliver Stone](/wiki/Oliver_Stone "Oliver Stone") as a producer. Stone
brought in [Terry Hayes](/wiki/Terry_Hayes "Terry Hayes") as screenwriter, and
they developed a script titled _Return of the Apes_.[65] In their script,
humanity is threatened by an ailment encoded in their DNA, so two scientists
go back in time thousands of years to stop it at its origin. They discover the
disease was engineered by advanced apes to ensure humanity's eventual
destruction.[66] [Arnold Schwarzenegger](/wiki/Arnold_Schwarzenegger "Arnold
Schwarzenegger") committed to star as scientist Will Robinson, while [Philip
Noyce](/wiki/Philip_Noyce "Philip Noyce") agreed to direct. The draft
impressed Fox president [Peter Chernin](/wiki/Peter_Chernin "Peter Chernin"),
but other executives were ambivalent about the action script, believing it
should be lighter. Notably, executive Dylan Sellers insisted the script
include a comic scene involving apes playing baseball as his "stamp" on the
film, and fired Hayes when he left it out. This move caused Noyce to quit as
well, and subsequently almost everyone involved in the project left for one
reason or another.[65]

After the collapse of the Stone-Hayes project, Fox brought on [Chris
Columbus](/wiki/Chris_Columbus_\(filmmaker\) "Chris Columbus \(filmmaker\)")
to develop a new _Apes_ concept. Columbus hired [Sam Hamm](/wiki/Sam_Hamm "Sam
Hamm") to write a new draft taking elements from Boulle's novel and various
unused scripts. In Hamm's script, an ape astronaut from a distant planet
unleashes a devastating virus on Earth. Scientists go to the astronaut's
planet, where apes hunt humans; they locate a cure, but return to find Earth
overrun by simians. Schwarzenegger remained attached, but Fox found the script
underwhelming. Columbus left the project in 1995 after his mother's death, and
[James Cameron](/wiki/James_Cameron "James Cameron") stepped in to produce.
Cameron intended to go in a "very different direction" with the script, but
following the critical and financial success of his film
_[Titanic](/wiki/Titanic_\(1997_film\) "Titanic \(1997 film\)")_ , he dropped
out of the project. Fox approached a series of directors to take over, without
success. By 1999 the studio decided once again to go in a new direction.[67]

### _Planet of the Apes_
(2001)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Planet of the Apes \(2001\)")]

Main article: [Planet of the Apes (2001
film)](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(2001_film\) "Planet of the Apes \(2001
film\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Tim_Burton_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/150px-
Tim_Burton_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tim_Burton_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tim_Burton_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg "Enlarge")

[Tim Burton](/wiki/Tim_Burton "Tim Burton"), director of the 2001 _Planet of
the Apes_

In 1999, Fox hired [William Broyles, Jr.](/wiki/William_Broyles,_Jr. "William
Broyles, Jr.") to write a new script. Fox insisted on a July 2001 release
date, but otherwise offered considerable creative control.[67] This prospect
attracted director [Tim Burton](/wiki/Tim_Burton "Tim Burton"), who hoped to
do a "re-imagining" of _Planet of the Apes_. However, Burton found the
production arduous, largely due to Fox's strict release schedule. The studio
budgeted the film at $100 million, meaning Broyles' ambitious script had to be
rewritten to reduce costs; [Lawrence Konner](/wiki/Lawrence_Konner "Lawrence
Konner") and [Mark Rosenthal](/wiki/Mark_Rosenthal "Mark Rosenthal") worked on
rewrites even as the film entered production. The tight schedule meant all
stages of production were rushed.[68]

The film stars [Mark Wahlberg](/wiki/Mark_Wahlberg "Mark Wahlberg") as
astronaut [Leo Davidson](/wiki/Leo_Davidson "Leo Davidson"), who accidentally
travels through a wormhole to a distant planet where talking apes enslave
humans. He leads a human revolt and upends ape civilization by discovering
that the apes evolved from the normal earth primates who had accompanied his
mission, and arrived years before. [Helena Bonham
Carter](/wiki/Helena_Bonham_Carter "Helena Bonham Carter") played chimpanzee
[Ari](/wiki/Ari_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Ari \(Planet of the Apes\)"), while
[Tim Roth](/wiki/Tim_Roth "Tim Roth") played the human-hating chimpanzee
[General Thade](/wiki/General_Thade "General Thade"). The film received mixed
reviews, with critics generally believing it failed to compare to the
original. Much criticism focused on the confusing plot and twist ending,
though many reviewers praised the special effects.[69][70] The film succeeded
in the box office, taking in a total of $362,211,740.[71] Fox had initially
hoped for a second film, but the difficult production made Burton disinclined
to participate, and the film failed to generate enough interest for Fox to
pursue a sequel.[68]

## Reboot film
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Reboot film series")]

### _Rise of the Planet of the Apes_
(2011)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Rise of the Planet of the Apes \(2011\)")]

Main article: [Rise of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Rise of the Planet of the Apes")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg/150px-
Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Andy_Serkis_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis") portrayed Caesar via
[performance capture acting](/wiki/Performance_capture_acting "Performance
capture acting")

In 2005, screenwriters [Rick Jaffa and Amanda
Silver](/wiki/Rick_Jaffa_and_Amanda_Silver "Rick Jaffa and Amanda Silver")
developed a concept for a new _Planet of the Apes_ film, eventually titled
_[Rise of the Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Rise
of the Planet of the Apes")_. Inspired by news articles on apes raised as
humans and advances in genetics, Jaffa conceived an idea for a film about a
genetically enhanced chimp raised in a human household. He and Silver pitched
the concept to Fox as a way to [reboot](/wiki/Reboot_\(fiction\) "Reboot
\(fiction\)") the _Apes_ franchise by reinventing the story of the chimpanzee
[Caesar](/wiki/Caesar_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Caesar \(Planet of the Apes\)"),
the lead character of _Conquest_. Fox was impressed and bought the pitch, but
development struggled for five years as the production cycled through scripts,
writers, directors, and producers. In 2010, producers [Peter
Chernin](/wiki/Peter_Chernin "Peter Chernin") and Dylan Clark of Chernin
Entertainment stepped in to move the film forward, retaining Jaffa and Silver
as writers.[72][73]

In the final script, Caesar receives enhanced cognition from a viral drug
created by Will Rodman, who raises him. After being imprisoned in a primate
sanctuary, Caesar uses his ingenuity to launch an uprising.[74] The screenplay
contains numerous complex connections to other entries in the series, causing
some confusion as to its exact relation to them. Oliver Lindler writes that
while the film's premise might identify it as a [remake](/wiki/Remake
"Remake") of _Conquest_ , official dispatches and professional reviewers
typically avoided the term, instead calling the film a [prequel](/wiki/Prequel
"Prequel") or "origin story" to the original _Planet of the Apes_ film, and/or
a [reboot](/wiki/Reboot_\(fiction\) "Reboot \(fiction\)") of the series,
although fans and bloggers were more apt to make the "remake"
connection.[75][76][77] The completed script attracted director [Rupert
Wyatt](/wiki/Rupert_Wyatt "Rupert Wyatt"). To portray ape characters
realistically, the production avoided [practical
effects](/wiki/Practical_effects "Practical effects") and animal actors in
favor of [performance capture acting](/wiki/Performance_capture_acting
"Performance capture acting"), partnering with New Zealand visual effects
company [Weta Digital](/wiki/Weta_Digital "Weta Digital"). Wyatt cast [James
Franco](/wiki/James_Franco "James Franco") as Will Rodman, while veteran
performance capture actor [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis")
signed on to star as Caesar.[78]

_Rise_ debuted on August 5, 2011. Critics reviewed it positively, especially
praising the visual effects and Serkis' performance.[79] It was a major box
office hit, taking in $481,801,049 over its $93 million budget.[80] Weta's
special effects earned the film two [Visual Effects Society
Awards](/wiki/Visual_Effects_Society_Awards "Visual Effects Society Awards")
and an Oscar nomination at the [84th Academy Awards](/wiki/84th_Academy_Awards
"84th Academy Awards"), among other accolades. The strength of Serkis's
performance also inspired Fox to promote him for Oscar consideration, though
the Academy did not nominate him.[81] Following this success, Fox immediately
planned for a sequel.[82]

### _Dawn of the Planet of the Apes_
(2014)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Dawn of the Planet of the Apes \(2014\)")]

Main article: [Dawn of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/SDCC13_-_Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes_%289348023398%29.jpg/200px-
SDCC13_-_Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes_%289348023398%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:SDCC13_-_Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes_\(9348023398\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:SDCC13_-_Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes_\(9348023398\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Cast and crew of _[Dawn of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes")_
(from left): director [Matt Reeves](/wiki/Matt_Reeves "Matt Reeves") and stars
[Jason Clarke](/wiki/Jason_Clarke_\(actor\) "Jason Clarke \(actor\)"), [Keri
Russell](/wiki/Keri_Russell "Keri Russell"), and Andy Serkis

Producers Peter Chernin and Dylan Clark started planning the film eventually
titled _[Dawn of the Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes
"Dawn of the Planet of the Apes")_ just after _Rise_ 's release in 2011. Fox
gave the film a budget of $170 million and a release date of July 11,
2014.[83][84] Rick Jaffa and Amanda Silver returned to pen the script and
produce, and the studio quickly signed Andy Serkis to reprise his role as
Caesar. Director Rupert Wyatt withdrew from the project due to production and
scheduling issues, and was replaced by [Matt Reeves](/wiki/Matt_Reeves "Matt
Reeves").[83][85]

Set ten years after _Rise_ , the film establishes that the "Simian Flu" that
increased the intelligence of the apes has killed most humans. Caesar
struggles to maintain peace as his ape community is drawn into a war with
nearby human survivors. Weta Digital again provided special effects work,
which combined practical sets, digitally manipulated backgrounds, and
performance capture ape characters.[86] The human cast included [Jason
Clarke](/wiki/Jason_Clarke_\(actor\) "Jason Clarke \(actor\)") as Malcolm,
[Keri Russell](/wiki/Keri_Russell "Keri Russell") as Ellie, and [Gary
Oldman](/wiki/Gary_Oldman "Gary Oldman") as Dreyfus.[87] The film debuted on
July 11, 2014. It was met with critical acclaim; reviewers found it a strong
followup to _Rise_ and lauded the combination of an engaging script with
impressive special effects.[88][89] It also performed very strongly at the box
office, taking in $707,498,744 in worldwide grosses.[84] Its special effects
received several accolades, including three Visual Effects Society Awards and
an Oscar nomination at the [87th Academy Awards](/wiki/87th_Academy_Awards
"87th Academy Awards").[90]

### _War for the Planet of the Apes_
(2017)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: War for the Planet of the Apes \(2017\)")]

Main article: [War for the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "War for the Planet of the Apes")

The producers were confident enough in _Dawn of the Planet of the Apes_ that
they started planning for the next installment before production had
completed. They contracted Matt Reeves to return as director after seeing his
cut of _Dawn_ ; he also wrote the script with [Mark
Bomback](/wiki/Mark_Bomback "Mark Bomback"). Peter Chernin, Rick Jaffa and
Amanda Silver serve as producers.[91][92] The film, _[War for the Planet of
the Apes](/wiki/War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "War for the Planet of the
Apes")_ , was released on July 14, 2017.[93] [Woody
Harrelson](/wiki/Woody_Harrelson "Woody Harrelson") and [Gabriel
Chavarria](/wiki/Gabriel_Chavarria "Gabriel Chavarria") played human
characters, while [Steve Zahn](/wiki/Steve_Zahn "Steve Zahn") played Bad
Ape.[94][95] The film received overwhelmingly positive reviews.[96][97]

### Possible fourth
film[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Possible fourth film")]

In October 2016, it was announced that a fourth _Planet of the Apes_ film is
already being planned.[98][99]

## Other media and
merchandise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Other media and merchandise")]

### Books[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Books")]

[Pierre Boulle](/wiki/Pierre_Boulle "Pierre Boulle")'s novel _[La Planète des
Singes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(novel\) "Planet of the Apes \(novel\)")_
was translated and reprinted several times after its original publication in
1963.[100] In addition, all of the original sequels spawned
[novelizations](/wiki/Novelization "Novelization") by established science
fiction writers of the day, each of which went through multiple reprintings of
their own. [Michael Avallone](/wiki/Michael_Avallone "Michael Avallone") wrote
the novelization for _Beneath the Planet of the Apes_ in 1970. [Jerry
Pournelle](/wiki/Jerry_Pournelle "Jerry Pournelle"), who later co-authored
_[Lucifer's Hammer](/wiki/Lucifer%27s_Hammer "Lucifer's Hammer")_ and _[The
Mote in God's Eye](/wiki/The_Mote_in_God%27s_Eye "The Mote in God's Eye")_,
wrote the _Escape from the Planet of the Apes_ novelization. [John
Jakes](/wiki/John_Jakes "John Jakes"), former [Science Fiction Writers of
America](/wiki/Science_Fiction_Writers_of_America "Science Fiction Writers of
America") president, wrote _Conquest of the Planet of the Apes_. [David
Gerrold](/wiki/David_Gerrold "David Gerrold"), scriptwriter for the _[Star
Trek](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Original_Series "Star Trek: The Original Series")_
episode "[The Trouble with Tribbles](/wiki/The_Trouble_with_Tribbles "The
Trouble with Tribbles")", novelized _Battle for the Planet of the Apes_.
Novelizations of the live action and animated television series were also
produced.[101] [William T. Quick](/wiki/William_T._Quick "William T. Quick")
novelized the 2001 _Planet of the Apes_ ; he also wrote two
[prequel](/wiki/Prequel "Prequel") novels, and several other book tie-ins were
published.[102]

### Comics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Comics")]

Main article: [Planet of the Apes
(comics)](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(comics\) "Planet of the Apes \(comics\)")

_Planet of the Apes_ -based comics have been published regularly since 1968.
Among the most notable is [Marvel Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel
Comics")' _[Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(magazine\) "Planet
of the Apes \(magazine\)")_ magazine, published from 1974 to 1977. The black-
and-white series featured comics adaptations of each of the films, new _Apes_
stories by [Doug Moench](/wiki/Doug_Moench "Doug Moench"), series news,
essays, interviews and other material. It became one of Marvel's most
successful titles, attracting 300 to 400 fan letters with every issue, so many
that the studio had to suspend its practice of writing personal responses.
Marvel also published the monthly title _Adventures on the Planet of the Apes_
from 1975 to 1976, comprising color reprints of the _Planet_ and _Beneath_
adaptations.[103]

In 1990, during a resurgence of interest in the series, [Malibu
Comics](/wiki/Malibu_Comics "Malibu Comics") launched a new monthly black-and-
white _Planet of the Apes_ comic through its Adventure Comics studio. The
debut issue sold 40,000, a record for black-and-white comics, leading to a
successful run of 24 issues over two years. The series follows Caesar's
grandson and heir Alexander as he struggles to govern ape civilization. The
comic's success led Malibu to publish five four-issue spin-off
[miniseries](/wiki/Comic_miniseries "Comic miniseries"): _Ape City_ , _Planet
of the Apes: Urchak 's Folly_, the _[Alien Nation](/wiki/Alien_Nation "Alien
Nation")_ crossover _Ape Nation_ , _Planet of the Apes: Blood of the Apes_ ,
and _Planet of the Apes: The Forbidden Zone_. Malibu also published two [one-
shots](/wiki/One-shot_\(comics\) "One-shot \(comics\)"): _A Day on the Planet
of the Apes_ and _Planet_ prequel _Planet of the Apes: Sins of the Fathers_ ;
a [trade paperback](/wiki/Trade_paperback_\(comics\) "Trade paperback
\(comics\)") collecting the first four issues of the main series, titled
_Monkey Planet_ ; and reissues of stories from Marvel's earlier _Apes_
series.[104]

Other companies producing _Planet of the Apes_ comics include [Gold Key
Comics](/wiki/Gold_Key_Comics "Gold Key Comics"), [Dark Horse
Comics](/wiki/Dark_Horse_Comics "Dark Horse Comics"), and [Boom!
Studios](/wiki/Boom!_Studios "Boom! Studios"). In 2014, Boom! collaborated
with [IDW Publishing](/wiki/IDW_Publishing "IDW Publishing") on the _[Star
Trek](/wiki/Star_Trek "Star Trek")_ crossover _[Star Trek/Planet of the Apes:
The Primate
Directive](/wiki/Star_Trek/Planet_of_the_Apes:_The_Primate_Directive "Star
Trek/Planet of the Apes: The Primate Directive")_.[105]

### Toys and
merchandise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Toys and merchandise")]

The series, and particularly the live-action _Apes_ television show and the
_Return to the Planet of the Apes_ cartoon, generated numerous toy and
merchandising tie-ins. During the 1970s, Fox licensed around 60 companies to
produce about 300 different _Apes_ products, including action figures and
playsets, [model building](/wiki/Model_building "Model building") kits,
coloring books, [book-and-record sets](/wiki/Book-and-record_set "Book-and-
record set"), trading cards, [toy weapons](/wiki/Toy_weapon "Toy weapon"),
costumes, apparel, branded tableware, and lunch boxes. This level of
merchandising was unusual for the time, and the success of _Apes_ merchandise
may have inspired the campaigns that later became commonplace for films and
television series.[106] The action figures, sold by
[Mego](/wiki/Mego_Corporation "Mego Corporation") beginning in 1973, were the
first such toys sold as film tie-ins; they proved popular and inspired the
rise of action figure series based on popular culture franchises.[107] Eric
Greene writes that _Apes_ toys were popular enough to lead some contemporary
children to engage in apes-vs.-humans role-playing [make
believe](/wiki/Make_believe "Make believe") games that simulated the series'
conflicts in a manner similar to "Cowboys and Indians".[106] With the release
of the 21st-century films, Fox licensed several companies to manufacture new
_Apes_ toys, including detailed action figures of new and "classic" characters
sold as [collectibles](/wiki/Collectible "Collectible").[108]

### Theme park
ride[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Theme park ride")]

A _Planet of the Apes_ ride is planned for the [20th Century Fox
World](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox_World "20th Century Fox World") [theme
park](/wiki/Theme_park "Theme park") under construction in
[Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia "Malaysia").[109]

### Video
games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Video games")]

In 1983, 20th Century Fox Videogames developed a _Planet of the Apes_ game for
the [Atari 2600](/wiki/Atari_2600 "Atari 2600"), which was to be the first
computer game based on the series. However, the game was still in the
[prototype](/wiki/Prototype "Prototype") phase when Fox shuttered its game
division during the [video game crash of 1983](/wiki/Video_game_crash_of_1983
"Video game crash of 1983"), and never saw release. It was assumed lost until
2002, when collectors identified a prototype, found earlier in a case labeled
_Alligator People_ , as the missing _Apes_ game.[110][111] Independent
designers Retrodesign completed and released the game as _[Revenge of the
Apes](/wiki/Revenge_of_the_Apes "Revenge of the Apes")_ in 2003.[111] In the
game, the player controls Taylor as he fights apes across several levels
inspired by the film to reach the Statue of Liberty.[110]

A video game based on the series did not appear until 2001. [Fox
Interactive](/wiki/Fox_Interactive "Fox Interactive") began developing the
[_Planet of the Apes_ game](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(video_game\) "Planet of
the Apes \(video game\)") in 1998 for [PC](/wiki/PC_game "PC game") and
[PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation_\(console\) "PlayStation \(console\)") as a
tie-in to the long-gestating [remake
film](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(2001_film\) "Planet of the Apes \(2001
film\)"). Fox and [developer](/wiki/Video_game_developer "Video game
developer") [Visiware](/wiki/Visiware "Visiware") proceeded with the game when
the film went into limbo, creating their own story based on Boulle's novel and
the original films.[112][113] The game is an [action-adventure](/wiki/Action-
adventure_video_game "Action-adventure video game") in which players control
astronaut Ulysses as he explores an ape-ruled future Earth. Setbacks with the
film project and Fox Interactive's decision to co-publish with another company
([Ubisoft](/wiki/Ubisoft "Ubisoft")) delayed the game three years. Despite its
long development, the game missed the debut of Tim Burton's _Planet of the
Apes_ film by two months;[114] it finally appeared on September 20, 2001, to
mostly negative reviews.[115][116][117] Additionally, Ubisoft produced a
substantially different _Planet of the Apes_ game for [Game Boy
Advance](/wiki/Game_Boy_Advance "Game Boy Advance") and [Game Boy
Color](/wiki/Game_Boy_Color "Game Boy Color"), a [side-scroller](/wiki/Side-
scroller "Side-scroller") following the first two films.[113][118]

In 2014, Fox partnered with [Ndemic Creations](/wiki/Ndemic_Creations "Ndemic
Creations") on a substantial _[Dawn of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes")_
-themed update to the [mobile game](/wiki/Mobile_game "Mobile game") _[Plague
Inc.](/wiki/Plague_Inc. "Plague Inc.")_ Players create and spread a "Simian
Flu" virus to eradicate humans while helping apes survive.[119]

[Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis") has mentioned that _[War for
the Planet of the Apes](/wiki/War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "War for the
Planet of the Apes")_ would be accompanied by a video game, for which he
performed motion capture.[120] Titled _[Planet of the Apes: Last
Frontier](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes:_Last_Frontier "Planet of the Apes: Last
Frontier")_ , the game is set for release for the [PlayStation
4](/wiki/PlayStation_4 "PlayStation 4"), [Xbox One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One")
and [PC](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer") in fall 2017.[121]

## Themes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Themes")]

Critics consider [race](/wiki/Race_\(human_categorization\) "Race \(human
categorization\)") to be the _Planet of the Apes_ series' primary theme.[6]
Eric Greene, author of a book on the role of race in the original films and
spinoff material, writes that "when seen as one epic work, the _Apes_ saga
emerges as a liberal allegory of racial conflict."[35] In Greene's
interpretation, the franchise's plot arc is founded in the conflict between
humans and apes, who alternately subjugate one another in a destructive
cycle.[122] [Difference](/wiki/Difference_\(philosophy\) "Difference
\(philosophy\)") between human and ape manifests primarily in physical
appearance, and dominance derives from social power rather than innate
superiority. Each film shifts the power balance so that the audience
identifies sometimes with the humans, and other times with the apes.[123]
According to Greene, this arc's central message is that unresolved racial
discord inevitably leads to cataclysm.[122] Other critics have followed
Greene's interpretations.[124][125] Producers Abrahams and Jacobs did not
consciously intend the first film's racial undertones, and did not appreciate
them until [Sammy Davis Jr.](/wiki/Sammy_Davis_Jr. "Sammy Davis Jr.") pointed
them out in 1968.[126][127][128] Subsequently, the filmmakers incorporated the
theme more overtly in later installments; as a result, race moves from being a
secondary theme in the first two films, to becoming the major concern of the
last three.[129]

Several critics have written that the reboot films downplay the original
series' theme of race, generally arguing that this is to their
detriment.[130][131][132] Others, however, write that the films incorporate
racial themes in subtler ways.[133]

The [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") and the threat of [nuclear
holocaust](/wiki/Nuclear_holocaust "Nuclear holocaust") are major themes
introduced in Rod Serling's original _Planet of the Apes_ script.[7] The films
are [apocalyptic](/wiki/Apocalyptic_fiction "Apocalyptic fiction") and
[dystopian](/wiki/Dystopian "Dystopian"), and portray the era's tensions
leading to world destruction.[134][135] The films critique both sides of the
war, with the oppressive ape society and the mutant city featuring traits of
both Western culture and the Soviet bloc.[134][136] According to Greene, Cold
War themes were central to the first two films and some spinoff media, but
were less significant in the later sequels, which foregrounded racial conflict
instead.[137]

Questions of [animal rights](/wiki/Animal_rights "Animal rights") also figure
heavily in the series; Greene considers this related to the racial
themes.[138] The first film portrays Taylor treated cruelly by apes who
consider him an animal; in later films humans abuse apes for the same
reason.[139] The primate rights theme is much more dominant in the reboot
films, which directly invoke the question of [great ape
personhood](/wiki/Great_ape_personhood "Great ape personhood") in portraying
Caesar and his friends struggling for their rights in a society that does not
consider them [legal persons](/wiki/Legal_persons "Legal persons").[140]

## Cultural impact and
legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Cultural impact and legacy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/WonderCon_2011_-_Planet_of_the_Apes_costumes_%28Dr_Zaius_and_Dr_Zira%29_%285593337505%29.jpg/200px-
WonderCon_2011_-_Planet_of_the_Apes_costumes_%28Dr_Zaius_and_Dr_Zira%29_%285593337505%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:WonderCon_2011_-_Planet_of_the_Apes_costumes_\(Dr_Zaius_and_Dr_Zira\)_\(5593337505\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:WonderCon_2011_-_Planet_of_the_Apes_costumes_\(Dr_Zaius_and_Dr_Zira\)_\(5593337505\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Fans in costume as Dr. Zaius and Dr. Zira at a science fiction convention

_Planet of the Apes_ received popular and critical attention well after
production ended on the original films and television series.[17] Fans'
interest in the franchise continued through publications like [Marvel
Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics")' _[Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(comics\) "Planet of the Apes \(comics\)")_
magazine[103] and [science fiction
conventions](/wiki/Science_fiction_convention "Science fiction convention"),
where the series was sufficiently popular to inspire "apecons"—conventions
devoted entirely to films involving apes—in the 1970s.[141] The series'
distinctive ape costumes were employed in live appearances, including by
musician [Paul Williams](/wiki/Paul_Williams_\(songwriter\) "Paul Williams
\(songwriter\)") ([Virgil](/wiki/Virgil_\(Planet_of_the_Apes\) "Virgil
\(Planet of the Apes\)") from _Battle_) on _[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny
Carson](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_Starring_Johnny_Carson "The Tonight Show
Starring Johnny Carson")_ and by [Mike Douglas](/wiki/Mike_Douglas "Mike
Douglas") on _[The Mike Douglas Show](/wiki/The_Mike_Douglas_Show "The Mike
Douglas Show")_.[17] In the 1970s, fans Bill Blake and Paula Crist created
Cornelius and Zira costumes; their routine was convincing enough that Fox
licensed them to portray the characters at events.[142] The films earned
strong ratings when they aired on television after their releases, and various
stations rebroadcast them together in [marathons](/wiki/Marathon_\(media\)
"Marathon \(media\)") in later years.[143] The live-action television series
was re-formatted into five TV movies for further broadcast in 1981,[55] and
the [Sci-Fi Channel](/wiki/Sci-Fi_Channel "Sci-Fi Channel") ran both it and
the cartoon in the 1990s.[100]

_Planet of the Apes_ had a wide impact on subsequent popular media. In terms
of production, the series' success with sequelization, spinoffs, and
merchandising established a new model of [media
franchising](/wiki/Media_franchising "Media franchising") in Hollywood
filmmaking, in which studios develop films specifically to generate multi-
media franchises.[144] In terms of content, the series influenced various
films and television productions during the 1970s and '80s that used science
fiction settings and characters to explore race relations, including _[Alien
Nation](/wiki/Alien_Nation "Alien Nation")_ , _[Enemy
Mine](/wiki/Enemy_Mine_\(film\) "Enemy Mine \(film\)")_ , and
_[V](/wiki/V_\(science_fiction\) "V \(science fiction\)")_. More direct
influence can be seen in [DC Comics](/wiki/DC_Comics "DC Comics")' 1972–1978
series _[Kamandi: The Last Boy on Earth](/wiki/Kamandi:_The_Last_Boy_on_Earth
"Kamandi: The Last Boy on Earth")_ and the Japanese franchise _[Time of the
Apes](/wiki/Time_of_the_Apes "Time of the Apes")_ , which concern human
protagonists in post-apocalyptic worlds ruled by talking animals.[55] [Mel
Brooks](/wiki/Mel_Brooks "Mel Brooks")' 1987 science fiction spoof
_[Spaceballs](/wiki/Spaceballs "Spaceballs")_ lampooned the Statue of Liberty
ending from the original _Planet_.[145]

Interest in the series resurged in the 1990s, as plans for a new film and
other media circulated. Greene attributes this renewed interest to a
combination of "pop culture nostalgia and baby boomer economics", as well as a
"political ferment" rising at the time that hearkened back to the period when
the films were first released.[146] Inspired particularly by the publication
of the [Malibu Comics](/wiki/Malibu_Comics "Malibu Comics") series, during
this period fans founded new clubs, websites, and [fanzines](/wiki/Fanzine
"Fanzine") active in the U.S., Canada, Brazil, and other countries.[147]
Companies began producing new branded merchandise, including clothing, toys,
and costumes.[148]

Especially after the 1990s, artists in diverse media referenced, incorporated,
or were otherwise influenced by the series. _Planet of the Apes_ turned up in
songs by various musicians, references in films, comedy bits by [Dennis
Miller](/wiki/Dennis_Miller "Dennis Miller") and [Paul
Mooney](/wiki/Paul_Mooney_\(comedian\) "Paul Mooney \(comedian\)"), and an
episode of _[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night
Live")_ hosted by Charlton Heston. _[The Simpsons](/wiki/The_Simpsons "The
Simpsons")_ parodied the series several times.[145] Notably, the episode "[A
Fish Called Selma](/wiki/A_Fish_Called_Selma "A Fish Called Selma")" features
the washed-up actor [Troy McClure](/wiki/Troy_McClure "Troy McClure") starring
in a [Broadway musical](/wiki/Broadway_musical "Broadway musical") adaptation
called _Stop the Planet of the Apes, I Want to Get Off!_[149] Artist [Martha
Rosler](/wiki/Martha_Rosler "Martha Rosler") incorporated footage of Cornelius
and Zira's interrogation from _Escape_ in her
[installation](/wiki/Installation_art "Installation art") "Global Taste: A
Meal in Three Courses", while [Guillermo Gómez-
Peña](/wiki/Guillermo_G%C3%B3mez-Pe%C3%B1a "Guillermo Gómez-Peña") and [Coco
Fusco](/wiki/Coco_Fusco "Coco Fusco") employed video from _Planet_ in a 1993
[performance art](/wiki/Performance_art "Performance art") piece at the
[Whitney Museum of American Art](/wiki/Whitney_Museum_of_American_Art "Whitney
Museum of American Art").[150]

The series' impact has also extended to the political sphere, and groups of
various leanings have employed its themes and imagery in their discourse.[151]
The phrase "planet of the apes" has been used for an overturning of the
political or racial _status quo_.[152] Eric Greene writes that it is
especially popular among [racial nationalists](/wiki/Racial_nationalism
"Racial nationalism") and reactionaries of different stripes, who use it in
reference to race conflict.[153] According to Greene, [white
supremacists](/wiki/White_supremacist "White supremacist") liken minority
advancement to the films' world in which supposed "inferiors" seize control,
while [black nationalists](/wiki/Black_nationalists "Black nationalists")
subvert the reference to celebrate the "racial apocalypse"; in this spirit,
[gangsta rap](/wiki/Gangsta_rap "Gangsta rap") group [Da Lench
Mob](/wiki/Da_Lench_Mob "Da Lench Mob") titled their 1994 album _[Planet of da
Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_da_Apes "Planet of da Apes")_. Greene writes that these
uses invert the anti-racist message of the films.[154] _Planet_ 's final image
of the ruined Statue of Liberty has become a common political reference; for
example, [Greenpeace](/wiki/Greenpeace "Greenpeace") used it in an advertising
campaign against [nuclear testing](/wiki/Nuclear_testing "Nuclear testing").
The series' themes and imagery have been invoked in political discussions on
topics as varied as [Sixties](/wiki/Sixties "Sixties") culture, urban decay,
contemporary wars, and gun violence.[155]
